--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
> 
> > I don't think that's true. I don't see how having an additional
> > org.something.util.CalendarParser class could make any library
harder to
> > understand and use. Hell, that class could even be extracted to a
different
> > binary, so that an outside developer wouldn't see it at all.
> 
> Have you really never tried to work your way through a mess of JavaDoc 
> with no easy way to figure out what classes you needed and what you 
> could ignore? Has it been that long since you learned a new API? 
> Featuritis isn't just a problem for applications. It applies to 
> libraries too. Smaller is better. Too large an API becomes a problem.

Which is why you can partition your deliverable into an API and a
runtime JAR. What's wrong with that suggestion?

You keep missing the distinction between "public" and "published":
"published" is a social convention enforced by social contracts.
Providing a runtime JAR, to be available at _runtime_, and not
_compile time_, is an excellent way of enforcing these conventions.
Similarly, excluding packages from JavaDoc works well.

How long has it been since I learned a new API? About 27 hours, from
first experience to plugging it into an existing application with all
tests passing. Oh, and that API had a runtime jar and an API jar. ;)
